definitions.definition: To put (someone or something) in a specific location .
examples: He placed the glass on the table.

definitions.definition: To earn a given spot in a competition; to rank at a certain position ( ( often followed by an ordinal ) ).
examples: The Cowboys placed third in the league.
Run Ragged was placed fourth in the race.

subdefinitions.definition: To finish second, especially of horses or dogs.
examples: In the third race: Aces Up won, paying eight dollars; Blarney Stone placed , paying three dollars; and Cinnamon showed, paying five dollars.

definitions.definition: To remember where and when (an object or person) has been previously encountered.
examples: I've seen him before, but I can't quite place where.
The librarian was placed at home by her neighbor at the time of the murder.

definitions.definition: To sing (a note) with the correct pitch .

examples: I placed ten dollars on the Lakers beating the Bulls.

definitions.definition: To recruit or match an appropriate person for a job , or a home for an animal for adoption , etc.
examples: They phoned hoping to place her in the management team.

definitions.definition: To assign (more or less value) to something.
examples: My workplace places a high premium on team spirit.
She places little value on religion.

main_definition: ( transitive ) To put (someone or something) in a specific location .
secondary_definitions: ( ergative ) To earn a given spot in a competition; to rank at a certain position ( ( often followed by an ordinal ) ).
( transitive ) To remember where and when (an object or person) has been previously encountered.
( transitive ) To vouch for someone's alibi.
( transitive ) To sing (a note) with the correct pitch .
( transitive ) To recruit or match an appropriate person for a job , or a home for an animal for adoption , etc.
( transitive ) To assign (more or less value) to something.
